There are various issues with Firebug
since it doesn't live in mozilla-central, it's hard to have automated tests that test it all the time
because it needs to run with older versions of Firefox, the Firebug devs have a tendency to hack around platform bugs/limitations rather than just fix them
I think the solution is dropping the "need" to run with older versions and evolve the two together, but anyway...
Has anyone noticed any regressions in canvas rendering in latest chrome (5.x) and webkit nightlies? Doesn't happen in Safari 4.x

persistent web apps? ;>

hsivonen: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.xml.sax.InputSource cannot be cast to nu.validator.xml.TypedInputSource when starting validator.nu
Did I do something obvious wrong?
jgraham: no, you didn't. that's the #1 V.nu local use FAQ
jgraham: have you tried rerunning python build/build.py localent?
hsivonen: There is an FAQ? I should have checked, really...
hsivonen: running that didn't make any difference
(where is the FAQ?)
Oh it works now
No idea if I changed anything
jgraham: nothing changed -- the problem is that the build always fails with that message the first time you run it
from a fresh checkout
Ummm....
running the build a second time fixes it
that rebuilds the necessary localent stuff
it's definitely something that should be changed in the build file
Ah, OK
MikeSmith, hsivonen: thanks for the help
I guess we could work around it for now by tweaking the build file to cause the build to be run twice the first time you check out

hi i wanted to ask about webstorage in HTML5.. When we use the anonymous functions in the callback like executeSql i think I  am facing there are some scope related problems while setting variables ...  does any one know how to safely set the scope of local variables from inside of anonymous functions?
am new to js...
sid__: Possibly you just need to use "var foo = bar" rather than "foo = bar". Otherwise I don't understand the question
using the var statement should help
Javascript is so awesome. How could making variables lobal by default possibly go wrong?
*global
finds function-scoping much more annoying than default-global
jgraham: At least ECMAScript doesn't ahve that behaviour inherently
As opposed to block scoping?
Yes
gsnedders: Huh?
Most (all?) ES shells will throw ReferenceError if you do (function(){foo=1;})();

(since I want to do "for (var i = 0; i < 4; ++i) setTimeout(function() { alert(i) }, 100)" etc, instead of having to write it more like "for (var i = 0; i < 4; ++i) (function(i){setTimeout(function() { alert(i) }, 100)})(i)")
gsnedders: No they won't
wonders what he's misremebering
gsnedders: They way that variablke scoping works in ECMAScript?
http://pastebin.com/n8Yk4fQ6
hi here is an example
the variable var1
Philip`: That is a pretty special case
is not getting set...
Philip`: (although I don't disagree)
jgraham: one simple way would be to make a class for call backs and set the variables to fetch from there... but is there a simpler way?
jgraham: I encountered it several times before understanding what the problem really was
mostly when doing stuff like dynamically creating lots of scripted buttons
Philip`: Ah, I have never done that
Is this all about understanding of closures?
sid__: I assume your problem is that the callback is async so it hasn't been run when the function returns
(the closure stuff looks fine)
jgraham: So how to solve this?
sid__: I don't know what you are actually trying to achieve
But you don't want to block on an SQL query running
well i am trying to return a result set to a calling function...
do i use the synchronus stuff mentioned in the w3c standard?
The database API is asynchronous, so you can't return a result from it synchronously
Philip`: there is a section 4.4 that says someting about syncro stuff http://dev.w3.org/html5/webdatabase
Oh, okay
doesn't actually know anything about the database API
oh!
so the only way to process is supplying a call back function?
as in when the query completes...
Looks like the synchronous API is only available in workers, not in normal web page scripts
so you have to use the async one
hmm
no but
i think
which means using a callback function instead of a return value
Thnks!
was about to split my head over that!
(It's a bit of a pain that you have to rearchitect large parts of the application when adding a single asynchronous operation into the middle of it)
Philip`: It's not really clear how to avoid that pain though
You can avoid it by starting with an asynchronous design
jgraham: there's no written FAQ. your question is just the most frequent question I get
(or using a programming environment that makes everything asynchronous automatically)
Philip`: perhaps some neat design pattern
probably event based tuff
stuff*
Philip`: and yes i will have to rewrite my app again :(
Philip`: Having a programming environement that makes everything async probably trades simplicity in simple cases for simplicity in complex cases
Although it is also likely appropriate for the web
sid__, you could use a worker
annevk: let me see...
annevk: so the use the synchronus elements instead of the asynchronus ones...Is the solution just that simple...?
BTW the only difference in the API is that the call back and the error functions are not there...
i mean the diff between API of the async and synchro stuff...
sid__: Workers can't e.g. access the DOM, so you'd have to tell a worker to do the database operations and then (asynchronously) get the results back and display them
so it wouldn't necessarily be much simpler
Workers seem more complex
In general
Does Mobile Safari even support workers?
sid__, the database interaction would be synchronous, but the UI interaction would be asynchronous
(I assume that's what you are targetting, although I would be happy to be wrong)
well i am making a scrapbook plugin for Chrome...:)
And saving the data in the provided webstorage
Ah OK
Well workers are a possibility then
the operations are to simply store and retrieve data elements
although I doubt they help much in this case
jgraham: I assume that i can simply return the result set *after the call completes* with workers to solve my problems...
Let me try\
Thanks
hsivonen, nice email
I hadn't read the specific approach Google was proposing yet. I agree that the centralized solution they propose is wrong.
annevk: thanks. do you know / can you say if Opera has reconsidered the widget stuff in light of the HTML5 app cache?
that is, if Opera were starting without a widget legacy, would there still be good reasons to do widgets instead of pinning stuff to HTML5 app cache?
opinions vary :)
annevk: I see
you can see some of them on http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapps/2010AprJun/ "[widgets] Zip vs GZip Tar"
Widgets make some sense for a limited set of use cases. There are still some things that widgets can do that web apps and app cache currently can't do well
sid__: Why do you need workers to do that?

Note to self: when Mozilla blog says "(can freeze your browser)", it means it.
It froze half my tabs in Chrome.
I'm impressed.
yay benchmark: http://hacks.mozilla.org/2010/05/better-performance-with-lazy-frame-construction/ opera 10.54: 2740ms/113ms, minefield: 1966ms/194ms, chrome dev: 80631ms/86ms
Oh, so you're saying it wasn't actually frozen, just spending 80 s doing the computation?
Oh well.
seems so
whoa, we should fix layout
annevk: we're not horribly slow like chrome
but clearly it can be optimized
oh wait, got the first number wrong
Chrome is amazingly terrible.  How real-world is this benchmark, I wonder?
zcorpan_, waiting for the day that layout is 10x faster
annevk: yeah, annoying javascript gets all the benchmark attention
s/benchmark/optimization/
zcorpan_: Easy to measure?
I mean as a reason that js gets all the attention
Although it is really important for e.g. canvas games
bit of shame we called it "CACHE MANIFEST"
would be kind of natural to use that file for application data
though I guess we could just ignore the name and all
WebKit can actually do lazy construction of render objects so I wonder why that benchmark is slow
othermaciej: Because it's not actually doing it?
gsnedders: my guess would be that something else is pathologically slow but I could be wrong
I don't think there is acttually an element with id="lastchild" in the document
I bet what happens is our getElementById is slow when no element with that id is present, or something like that
so container.insertBefore(div, lastchild) ends up being just a funny way to say container.append(div)
Maybe it's the if (/AppleWebKit/.test(navigator.userAgent)) { for (i = 0; i < 1000000000; i++); } part that does it.
That was exciting.
This is why I use Linux!
First my mouse cursor disappeared.
It seems like it might be a video driver issue, according to posts I read on the forums, and no one had any fixes, but rebooting was a workaround.
So then I tried restarting X.
This just shut my monitors off.
Then I tried rebooting.
To an old kernel.

But it seems my 10.04 userspace doesn't like the 9.10 kernel, because it gave me this cool effect of only using the top half of one of my monitors, with the bottom half being noise, and attempts to change the resolution resulting in even crazier effects.
So I rebooted again.
And now it works, for now.
<3 Ubuntu.

also, "dates" are weird. i once went out with an american gal and she had difficulties to comprehend the "split the bill" part. also, she smoked. but on the plus side, she moved whenever the wind was blowing the smoke in my direction, huh ?
"Come here I think you're beautiful/I think you're beautiful, beautiful/Some kind of stranger come inside"
I had to give up on a girl when I learned she was a smoker.  :/
erlehmann: Americans are weird.

I still maintain that Orthodox Jews have it best.  Someone sets you up, and both parties are very clear that they're only looking for marriage.  Thus two people will rarely have to date for more than a few weeks.  None of this angst about what the exact status is.
annevk, charles stross should write a science fiction story where the WHATWG takes over government business after a major disaster, due to some laws refering (!) to HTML standards :P
But yeah, american dates are either (1) paid for by the guy, if he asked the girl out, or (2) *maybe* split, if the girl asked the guy out.
I laugh at all the people who spend their teenage years agonizing over their girlfriend/boyfriend.
Something like a movie is easier to split, but food usually isn't.
TabAtkins, i once kissed a friend just right after she was having a cigarette, just to see how it is. awful, as expected — but the smell went away after we both drank more wine ;)
AryehGregor: That sounds like many other systems
Also Christmas.  It sounds like it would be horrible to have to think of presents to give to everyone you know.
AryehGregor: Well, I was apparently meant to go to aerobics this evening to meet some girl. I said no. :P
AryehGregor, I laugh at all people. period.

Of course, celebrating a totally different set of holidays from everyone else around you is a real pain.  Part of why I'm thinking of moving to Israel.

erlehmann: Does the new Ministry of Standards decide that all laws should be compatible with how people already behave?

Yeah, food is easy to split.  I've done it lots of times when going to a restaurant with random friends.
Split bills are rather common here
Much more so than in the UK
Typically everyone goes up to the counter and pays

Although you have to remember what you ordered
You don't even need to look together in the UK to get a single bill.
mbrubeck, it would be awesome if laws reflected reality, instead of most of them being totally unenforced.

Pepperoni pizza isn't kosher, it mixes milk with meat.

Anyway, I subsist on two specific types of cereal that I buy in enormous quantities, plus sometimes one particular brand of frozen pizza, plus sometimes one particular brand of packaged macaroni and cheese, plus ~2L of caffeine-free Diet Pepsi per day, plus whatever my mother makes.
This is enough variety for me.
Are the two cereals Count Chocula and Cap'n Crunch?
Because if not, your choices are wrong.
AryehGregor, are those food regulations only for orthodox people or do normal religious people also obey them ?
No, they're Quaker Oatmeal Squares (eaten without milk as a snack) and Honey Nut Cheerios (with milk as breakfast).  Currently.  I switch to different cereals sometimes, like once every few months.
I require all of my cereals to have the initials "CC".
So I guess Cookie Crisp counts.
TabAtkins, Create a CC licensed CC recipe.
Aw yiss.

erlehmann, a baseline definition of "religious Orthodox Jew" is "observes the Sabbath and eats only kosher food".  Most Jews aren't religious, though.  Reform and secular Jews don't believe in keeping kosher, Conservative Jews theoretically do but few of them actually do in practice.
TEH MOAR YOU KNOW
thank, AryehGregor

Of course, there are about fourteen zillion additional laws to obey beyond the Sabbath and kosher, but those two are among the most visible, burdensome, and socially important, so they're a pretty good indicator of whether you keep most of the rest.
TabAtkins, I eat those sugary cereals sometimes, but they get tiresome when I eat the same thing for three months in a row.
I could eat count chocula every single day and be happy with it.
But I don't eat cereal anymore - for several years breakfast was always cheese+crackers+juice, and now I eat eggs most mornings.
Do jews that don't observe the sabbath and eat only kosher usually ignore it completely, or make up some kind of light/diet version?
believes count chocula to be the perfect food.

AryehGregor: Yeah, but the chefs at google prepare them for me.
